Graphical abstract In this paper, we report on a new catalyst type based on Mg/Ga/O for the gas-phase methylation of phenol with the aim of obtaining the synthesis of 2,4,6-trimethylphenol. This catalyst showed an outstanding performance compared to similar catalysts reported in the literature, with high yield to the desired product. Reasons for this excellent performance were related to the high activity in methanol dehydrogenation to formaldehyde, which is the rate-limiting step in the multi-step (but one-pot) process, as well as to the moderate acidic features due to Ga sites, which enhanced the intramolecular rearrangement of O-alkylated compounds. The surprising role for co-fed steam, which greatly enhanced the selectivity to 2,4,6-trimethylphenol, was also investigated, combining reactivity experiments, in-situ FT-IR spectroscopy, and DFT calculations. It was found that the co-adsorption of water significantly affects the chemo-selectivity of the reaction, thus decreasing the formation of O-alkylated compounds in favour of the desired C-alkylated compounds. Reasons for catalyst deactivation were also studied. Keywords Phenol methylation Mg/Ga mixed oxides Trimethylphenols Role of water 1 Introduction 2,3,6-Trimethylphenol (2,3,6-TMP) and 2,4,6-trimethylphenol (2,4,6-TMP) are starting materials for vitamin E (tocopherols, tocotrienols) synthesis. The latter also serves as a co-monomer for the modification of polyphenyleneoxide (PPO) resins, and is used as an antioxidant in food, fodder, and cosmetics [1]. 2,3,6-TMP is produced by the gas-phase methylation of m-cresol with methanol at 300–460 °C, with an inlet methanol/m-cresol molar ratio which may be as high as 6–8; in fact, a relevant fraction of methanol decomposes to H2, CH4, and CO2. The typical catalyst is based on Fe oxide, modified with dopants such as Zn, Cr, and Sn, and yields as high as 90–95% can be obtained at a virtually complete conversion of m-cresol. For example, a yield of 97% to 2,3,6-TMP is reported with a catalyst consisting of Fe, Si, Al, and K oxides in a fixed bed [2]. 2,3,6-TMP can also be obtained by the methylation of 2,6-xylenol with an Al2O3 catalyst, but the selectivity achieved is no higher than 50% at limited xylenol conversion [3], in presence of solid acid catalysts. Another class of catalysts investigated for m-cresol methylation is based on doped MgO, either in the liquid or in the gas phase, but in this case, also, yields to 2,3,6-TMP are either nil or low [4–10]. 2,4,6-TMP (mesitol) is produced in the gas-phase methylation of phenol, o-cresol, or 2,6-xylenol with MgO-based catalysts, with dopants such as Fe oxide, V oxide, or others; also in this case, methanol is fed in great excess compared to the phenolic reactant, with an inlet molar ratio which is a function of the phenolic compound used [1]. In this case, depending on the type of reactant fed, the selectivity to the 2,4,6-TMP can be either high (from 2,6-xylenol), or relatively low (from phenol), depending also on the reaction conditions used. A schematic overview on phenol methylation products with the main synthetic routes toward 2,3,6-TMP and 2,4,6-TMP is reported in Scheme 1 . The literature on phenol methylation to o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol is very extensive, whereas that dealing with the methylation of phenolics for the direct synthesis of TMPs is very scarce [10–21]. In fact, under the typical conditions used for experiments carried out on lab scale, a high selectivity to ortho mono-methylated and di-methylated products can be achieved with catalysts with basic features and using phenol as the starting reactant, whereas tri-methylated products are obtained with low selectivity even at total conversion. In general, it is a characteristic of these catalyst types, based either on Mg/M metal oxides or V/M (M = Fe, Cr, etc.), to be extremely regio- and chemo-selective; in fact, in phenol methylation the introduction of the methyl group occurs almost exclusively in ortho positions (leading to o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol as the main products), whereas the substitution in the para position is more difficult to achieve. For example, in order to achieve high selectivity to 2,4,6-TMP, it is necessary to start from 2,6-xylenol, thus using a two-step process from phenol, or recycling the products of phenol (o-cresol) methylation in order to push further the ring methylation. Despite these established industrial technologies, one aim of the industry is to develop a process for the direct methylation of phenol to 2,4,6-TMP; another aim is the replacement of m-cresol with either phenol or o-cresol for 2,3,6-TMP synthesis. Ideally, a catalyst showing a high selectivity from phenol to either of the two TMP isomers, depending on reaction conditions, would be a remarkable achievement. In previous works, we reported on the mechanism of phenol methylation with methanol in the gas phase, catalysed by basic Mg/M mixed oxides (M = Cr, Fe, Al) [22–25]. We demonstrated that this mechanism does not involve the generally accepted electrophilic attack of the methyl group on the aromatic ring, but consists of a sequence of steps in which the dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde is rate-determining, followed by the ring-hydroxymethylation by the aldehyde on the aryl ring, and the final hydrogenolysis of salicylic alcohol to produce the desired o-cresol, and then 2,6-xylenol with a similar mechanism [26,27]. In this respect, catalysts showing enhanced dehydrogenative properties are more active than those based on alkali or alkaline earth oxides; for example, Mg/Fe/O and Mg/Cr/O were shown to be considerably more active than MgO. Therefore, the aim of achieving high selectivity to the products of phenol poly-methylation (TMPs) requires components which are very active in methanol dehydrogenation, whereas the presence of a basic component is needed in order to generate the phenolate species. In addition to Cr3+ and Fe3+, Ga3+ shows enhanced properties in dehydrogenation [28–32]; therefore, we decided to investigate the catalytic properties of Mg/Ga mixed-oxide catalysts. The use of Ga as a catalyst component in MgO-based systems has been already described in literature; for example, Ga-containing layered double hydroxides (LDH) are possible precursors of mixed-oxide catalysts; Ga3+ is claimed to be incorporated in the structure of MgO after the calcination treatment of the LDH. Therefore, the physico-chemical properties of these materials have been investigated in numerous studies [33–38]. The use of Ga-containing mixed oxides as basic catalysts, and the characteristics and reactivity of Mg/Al/Ga/O hydrotalcites, both uncalcined and calcined, in the Knoevenagel condensation reaction of benzaldehyde and cyanoacetate was reported [39]. The authors concluded that Ga-containing oxides possess the higher density of basic sites, and are more active in Knoevenagel condensation. In relation to the use of Ga-containing systems as catalysts for aromatic alkylation, the following papers have been published (liquid-phase alkylation using GaCl3 as a Lewis-type acid is not included here): (a) Ga3+ was used as the exchange cation in zeolite ZSM-12, to affect the catalytic acid-type activity in naphthalene methylation with methanol; some regio-selectivity effect due to the presence of Ga was observed [40]; (b) Ga3+ and Al3+-substituted SBA-15 were used as acid catalysts for the gas-phase N-methylation of aniline. Also in this case, some effect on selectivity was attributed to the modification of acidity inferred by the presence of Ga [41]; (c) Ga-exchanged β-zeolites were used for the gas-phase methylation of phenol, however, no special chemo- or regio-selectivity, or activity improvement, were reported, compared to unmodified zeolite [42a]; (d) the spinel MgGa2O4 was studied as catalyst for the benzylation of benzene [42b]; and (e) Ga-exchanged MFI zeolites were used for acid-catalysed toluene methylation; the restriction of pores by exchanged cations induced some effects of regioselectivity [43]. Regioselectivity effects were also reported in the methylation of m-cresol over Ga-exchanged ZSM-11 zeolites [44]; (e) GaAl12-pillared clay catalysts were used for the acid-catalysed methylation of toluene to xylenes; the introduction of Ga led to a slightly higher activity in toluene conversion which was attributed to the increased acidity [45a]. In one paper only the role of Ga as a promoter for MgO in phenol alkylation is briefly mentioned [45b], but the catalyst did not yield TMPs at all, neither was the role of Ga investigated in detail. Here we report on the catalytic behaviour of Mg/Ga mixed oxides in the gas-phase methylation of phenol. Catalysts showed an outstanding selectivity to 2,4,6-TMP, but unfortunately their selectivity declined with increasing catalyst deactivation. The reasons for the deactivation and the unusual regio-selectivity shown were investigated in depth, thus enabling us to suggest the role of the water generated in-situ on the catalytic performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterisation In this paper, samples are represented either with their formula for single-metal oxide samples (MgO and Ga2O3), or with the Mg/Ga atomic ratio for mixed-oxide samples. The single-metal oxides, magnesium oxide (MgO) and gallium oxide (Ga2O3) were synthesized by means of a precipitation method in which the nitrates (Mg(NO3)2*6H2O and Ga(NO3)3*9H2O for MgO and Ga2O3 respectively), were used as metal precursors and dissolved in distilled water (1 mol/L); the solution was then added dropwise to a second solution of Na2CO3*10H2O (1 mol/L in distilled water), under magnetic stirring, at 60 °C. The pH value was kept between 9.9 and 10.1 and monitored with an Amel Instrument 380, calibrated with two buffers at pH 7 and 13. The obtained magnesium hydroxide was filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried overnight at 110 °C. The material was then crushed and calcined at 450 °C for 5 h to produce MgO. The obtained gallium hydroxide was filtered and washed with distilled water to remove nitrates and sodium, and dried overnight at 90 °C. The precursor was then crushed and calcined at 450 °C for 8 h to produce the desired Ga2O3. Mg/Ga mixed oxides with Mg/Ga atomic ratios equal to 2 and 10 were synthesized by a co-precipitation procedure. This method consists of a simultaneous precipitation of metal hydroxides at controlled pH and temperature. A solution of the desired molar ratio between Mg(NO3)2*6H2O and Ga(NO3)3*9H2O (cation concentration 1 mol/L in distilled water) was added dropwise under stirring to a solution containing Na2CO3*10H2O (1 mol/L in distilled water). Sodium carbonate was used in excess compared to the stoichiometric amount required for the formation of hydrotalcite. The pH was maintained between 9.9 and 10.1 during all the syntheses and monitored with an Amel Instrument 380, calibrated with two buffers at pH 7 and 13. The precipitate was filtered and washed with distilled water (to remove the nitrates and sodium), and dried overnight at 110 °C. The precursor was then crushed and calcined at 450 °C for 8 h to produce the desired mixed oxide. XRD powder patterns of catalysts were recorded with a Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) on a Philips X'Pert vertical diffractometer equipped with a pulse height analyser and a secondary curved graphite-crystal monochromator. The analysis of the phases present in the patterns were performed using Bragg’s Law to calculate the crystalline d values and comparing them with those reported in literature and collected in the ICDD database (International Centre for Diffraction Data). The BET surface area of catalysts was determined by N2 absorption–desorption at liquid N2 temperature using a Sorpty 1750 Fison instrument. 0.2 g of the sample was typically used for measurement, and the sample was outgassed at 150 °C before N2 absorption. TGA analyses of the exhausted catalysts were performed with a SDT Q 600 instrument. 20 mg of the sample was typically used for the measurement, at temperatures ranging from room temperature up to 700 °C, with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, in air flux of 100mL/min. Ammonia thermal programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was measured with a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 analyser. Samples were placed in a quartz tube and pre-treated with a 20 mL/min of a 5% O2 in Ar flow and heated up to 450 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min (temperature maintained for 30 min). The temperature was then reduced to 100 °C and a mixture of 10% NH3 in helium (20 mL/min) was passed through the sample for 20 min. The sample was then purged with helium until the baseline was stabilised. The NH3 desorption rate was subsequently monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) at a heating rate of 5 °C/min up to 800 °C under helium flow (20 mL/min). 2.2 Reactivity experiments Alkylation catalytic tests were carried out by the vaporisation of a methanol/phenolic compound (phenol or 2,6-xylenol) liquid mixture (with the desired methanol to aromatic molar ratio, either 10:1 or 5:1, depending on the phenolic reactant); liquid flow was 0.0077 mL/min in a N2 stream (gas flow 20 mL/min). Phenol was supplied by VWR chemicals, 99+% purity; 2,6-xylenol was supplied by Sigma Aldrich, 99+% purity; methanol HPLC grade was supplied by Sigma Aldrich, purity 99%. The liquid mixture was fed by means of a syringe pump (KDScientific Legacy Syringe-infusion Pump). The usual composition of the feed gas was as follows (molar fractions): methanol 0.153, phenol 0.015, and nitrogen 0.832. In catalytic tests with steam co-feeding, water was added to the mixture (with a water-to-phenolic compound molar ratio equal to 10:1 or 5:1) and considered as inert, thus balancing the nitrogen flux. Total pressure was atmospheric. The gas/vapour stream was fed into a tubular glass reactor (length 450 mm, inner diameter 19 mm) containing 1 cm3 of catalyst in the form of 250–595 μm particles. The residence time was 1 s; each test was carried out by loading fresh catalyst. Catalyst particles were prepared by pressing the calcined powder to obtain a tablet, which was then crushed through sieves to obtain the desired particle size. During catalytic experiments, the reactor exit stream was condensed in 25 mL of HPLC-grade 2-propanol for around 50 min. The products condensed in 2-propanol were analysed by gas chromatography. 20 μL of decane was added to the solution as external standard. Products were analysed and quantified using a gas-chromatograph Thermo Focus GC model equipped with a non-polar capillary column Agilent HP-5 (5% phenyl – 95% methyl siloxane) having dimensions of 25 m x 320 μm x 1.05 μm. The injector was kept at a temperature of 280 °C in the split mode (30:1), the carrier gas was nitrogen (1.2 mL/min in column). The volume of solution injected for each analysis was 0.5 μL. In the standard programmed temperature, the oven remained in the isotherm at 50 °C for two minutes, then started the ramp of 20 °C/min to reach 280 °C, where it stayed isothermally for five minutes. Methanol decomposition tests were performed using the same apparatus as described above, but the light compounds were monitored on-line by an Agilent 3000A micro-GC with 3 parallel columns: (a) a PlotQ column, with He carrier, for the separation of CH4, CO2, H2O and methanol; (b) a OV1 column, with He carrier, for the separation of CO2, formaldehyde, H2O, and ethanol; (c) a Molecular Sieve 5A column, Ar carrier, for the separation of H2, O2, N2, CH4, and CO. A Plot U backflash column was installed to avoid CO2 and H2O poisoning in the third column. Yields of each product were calculated by the same method as described in detail in Ref. [46] 2.3 In-situ FT-IR spectroscopy The reagent adsorption on catalytic systems was investigated by means of in-situ FT-IR spectroscopy in vacuum. Phenol and 2,6-xylenol adsorption over MgO and Mg/Ga 10:1 was investigated between 4000 and 200 cm−1 (NIR Near Infra-Red), using a Perkin Elmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer. First, the catalyst powder was pressed into the form of a thin rectangular tablet and placed on a quartz slide; the “slide” was placed in a cylindrical tube of quartz, wrapped in a heating band at its central part, and terminating with a window consisting of two tablets of KBr, through which the beam of the incident radiation passed. The “slide” was either skated appropriately in such a way to allow the catalyst to intercept the optical path, or positioned at the level of heating bands. This cylindrical quartz tube was at the extremity of the vacuum line which was connected upstream with two vacuum pumps: a mechanical pump used to push the vacuum up to values around 10-3 mbar and a diffusive pump used to reach a high vacuum up to 10−6 mbar. After a vacuum between 10−5 and 10−6 mbar was reached, the pre-treatment of the sample was started by heating it while checking, by means of IR, that all the impurities deposited on the surface had been removed. Afterwards, the sample was cooled and processed by the adsorption of the compound of interest. When IR spectra confirmed the adsorption of a significant amount of the sample molecule, the desorption step started, heating the sample and recording the IR spectra at regular temperature intervals. 2.4 Modelling approach Gas-phase electronic structure calculations were carried out using the Gaussian09 suites of codes and the B3LYP [47,48] density functional theory (DFT), including all the electrons in the calculations. The basis set used was 6-31++G(d,p). MgO nano-crystals were modelled using a cluster approach that was previously benchmarked for structure, energetics, and spectral properties [48–51], by evaluating any possible size effects on adsorption energies and structures by increasing the number of atom clusters while maintaining the overall species neutrality. This investigation led us to use the Mg16O16 cluster to limit polarisation effects due to vertexes and edges. The geometrical parameters of the MgO (cubic, dMgO = 2.1084 Å) clusters were kept frozen in all calculations, as minor effects would be expected for them [52], as well as for energetic quantities. Geometries for the adsorbed species (i.e. phenols, phenolates, water) were fully optimised; unfortunately, the size of the model MgO crystal prevented us from performing a full characterisation by means of frequency calculations. Putative structures for energy minima were built using data from our previous works, followed by a complete geometrical relaxation, keeping the MgO cluster constrained. As for the description of gas-phase thermodynamics, we used the same theory level applied for the calculations on clusters. Putative structures for reactants and products were built manually, fully optimised, while their nature was tested by computing vibrational frequencies. The latter were also used to estimate enthalpies and Gibbs energies via the harmonic oscillator approximation. To model possible effects due to the co-adsorption of phenolic species and water on pristine Ga2O3, we exploited a cluster approach used to rationalise differences in reactivity between Al2O3, Ga2O3, and In2O3 [53]. A (Ga2O3)4 aggregate was used to model the adsorption of oxygenated molecules onto a surface Ga3+ ion and their subsequent transformations; the size of the aggregate appeared sufficiently large to limit possible polarisation effects due to the edge vicinity. The same level of theory used for MgO was also applied to study the adsorption on gallium oxide; in the latter case, it was also possible to allow the full relaxation of the model crystal in order to investigate the presence of strain effects. The latter turned out to be minimal, and we are going to provide only the results obtained from fully minimised species. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The effect of gallium on chemical-physical and reactivity features of MgO-based catalysts The gas-phase phenol methylation was investigated with the aim to maximize the synthesis of 2,4,6-TMP. MgO was chosen as a reference catalyst because it is a well-known material able to activate the target reaction, in particular develop the phenolate species and, at high temperature (>400 °C), also perform methanol dehydrogenation to formaldehyde [26–32]. As reported in the Introduction, the in-situ activation of methanol to formaldehyde represents the key step of the reaction, since the aldehyde was shown to be the real alkylating agent, via hydroxyalkylation of the phenolate [22–27]. To enhance the dehydrogenating properties of MgO, the effect of the addition of Ga3+ was investigated. A series of samples with different Mg/Ga molar ratio was prepared. The surface area of the catalysts calcined in air at 450 °C for 8 h was 140 m2/g for MgO, 115 m2/g for Mg/Ga 10:1, 88 m2/g for Mg/Ga 2:1, and 56 m2/g for Ga2O3. X-Ray diffraction patterns of samples are shown in Fig. S1 (top), reported in the supplementary information (ESI) section. The presence of Ga3+ did not modify the MgO pattern, even with a considerable amount (i.e. in Mg/Ga = 2:1); indeed, no reflections are attributable to Ga2O3. Even a calcination treatment at an increasing temperature (see Fig. S1 bottom, in ESI section) did not lead to the formation of crystalline Ga oxide; indeed, an increase in sample crystallinity was observed, occurring with a concomitant slight decline of the surface area (103 m2/g after treatment at 650 °C for 8 h). There was no evidence indicating the formation of the spinel compound, MgGa2O4 [54]. HR-TEM analyses performed on calcined samples did not evidence segregated Ga2O3 particles and Ga appears to be homogeneously dispersed in the MgO matrix (see Fig. S2 in ESI). The pattern of Ga2O3, prepared with the same procedure as for MgO and Mg/Ga/O, although with a slightly different pH (see Experimental), corresponds to rhombohedral α-Ga2O3 (JCPDF 00-043-1013). We tried to characterise Mg/Ga/O samples with Raman spectroscopy but, due to the strong fluorescence, it was not possible to infer any useful information. The XRF analysis of samples (Table S1, ESI) confirmed the composition, with atomic Mg/Ga ratios close to the expected ones. These catalysts were tested for the target reaction, feeding a CH3OH:phenol mixture with molar ratio equal to 10, in a continuous tubular glass fixed-bed reactor at a reaction temperature of 400 °C and a contact time of 1 s. Figs. 1 a–c compare the catalytic results obtained with Mg/Ga 10:1, MgO and Ga2O3, respectively. MgO showed an initial phenol conversion close to 15% which stabilised after a few hour time-on-stream at a value close to 2%. In these conditions, the main products were o-cresol and anisole. In particular, at the beginning of the reaction, the selectivity to anisole was comparable to that of o-cresol while, over time, the former decreased in favour of the mono C-alkylated compound. Conversely, Ga2O3 showed an initial high conversion (close to 100%) that rapidly decreased due to the fast deactivation. Moreover, gallium oxide showed a different products distribution compared to MgO, with a very high chemo-selectivity toward C-alkylated compounds. Among the studied mixed oxides, the best catalytic performance was shown by catalyst Mg/Ga 10:1 (Fig. 1a). In fact, the presence of a small amount of Ga greatly improved phenol conversion and affected products distribution; phenol conversion was complete at the very beginning of reaction time, and only a slight deactivation occurred with prolonged time-on-stream. Therefore, the dispersed Ga ion in the Mg/Ga 10:1 sample is able to promote the dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde that rapidly reacts with phenol, at the same time avoiding the excessive concentration of the aldehyde on catalyst surface, which would be inductive of the formation of heavy compounds. In fact, the Ga-richer catalyst (Mg/Ga 2:1, Fig. S3) showed a faster deactivation rate due to the higher concentration of formaldehyde that promoted the formation of resin-like compounds. The latter formed by the attack of the mono-hydroxyalkylated compound (salicylic alcohol, rapidly dehydrogenated to salicylic aldehyde) [22–27] onto another phenolic compound with generation of dimers. Indeed, the deposition of heavy compounds on the catalyst surface was found to be proportional to both the Ga amount in the catalyst (for the mixed oxides) and to the inlet concentration of the phenolic compound, as demonstrated by TGA experiments reported in Table S2 ESI. An alternative explanation for deactivation is the reduction of Ga oxide (see below), which modifies surface properties [55]. The fresh Mg/Ga 10:1 catalyst showed 45% selectivity to 2,4,6-TMP, 35% selectivity to 2,6-xylenol, and minor selectivity to other alkylated phenolics, with traces of 2,3,6-TMP only. Along with catalyst deactivation, first there was a progressive decline of selectivity to tri-methylated phenols and a corresponding increase of selectivity to 2,6-xylenol; afterwards, the selectivity to this compound also decreased, and selectivity to o-cresol increased. Overall, the behaviour was that typically expected for a kinetically consecutive reaction pattern (phenol → o-cresol → 2,6-xylenol → 2,4,6-TMP), when the conversion is decreased. Other by-products were 2,6-dimethylanisole (2,6-DMA), trimethylanisoles (TMA), and heavier polyalkylated compounds (Others). A thermal treatment in air at 450 °C, performed after 500 min of reaction, restored the original catalytic behaviour (Fig. 1a). Mg/Ga 2:1 catalyst showed an intermediate reactivity between pure Ga2O3 and Mg/Ga 10:1 (see Figure S3 in the ESI). As already stated, while MgO led to the formation of o-cresol with anisole as the major by-product, and no trace of polymethylated compounds, all the Ga-containing samples showed relatively high selectivity to 2,6-xylenol (with negligible formation of 2,3- and 2,4-xylenols), and to 2,4,6-TMP (with only traces of 2,3,6-TMP) (see Figure S3 in ESI). The most important difference between samples, however, regards the selectivity to 2,4,6-TMP; in fact, at high conversion, Ga oxide showed a low selectivity to 2,4,6-TMP, whereas both Mg/Ga 2:1 and Mg/Ga 10:1 exhibited a selectivity to this compound higher than 40%. Therefore, the presence of these two elements, Mg and Ga, gave the catalyst some unexpected reactivity properties, in relation to activity, stability, and selectivity to 2,4,6-TMP; the performance, however, was clearly affected by the Mg:Ga atomic ratio. The high activity of Mg/Ga 10:1 catalyst in methanol dehydrogenation (which is the rate-limiting step in phenol methylation with basic catalysts) [22–27], was demonstrated by experiments carried out in the absence of phenol, under the same conditions as those reported in Fig. 1. The results of these tests are shown in Fig. 2 , plotting methanol conversion and yield to main products (H2, CO, CO2, dimethyl ether and H2O) based on reaction time. Formaldehyde yields ranged 0 to 0.7% upon increasing reaction time due to its fast decomposition to CO and H2. Small amounts of other products formed: CH4 (yield from 1 to 0.7%), and dimethoxy methane (from 0 to 0.7% yield). It is evident that this catalyst is by far more reactive than pure MgO in methanol dehydrogenation and decomposition (see, for instance, the reactivity of MgO in Refs. [22] and [23]). It was also shown that there is an initial period, lasting approximately 40–50 min, during which methanol was completely converted, H2 formed in high yield, CO and CO2 formed in similar amounts, and water also formed, whereas afterwards conversion decreased, CO2 and H2O formation rapidly dropped, and the yield to CO increased. Therefore, it seems that methanol was dehydrogenated on the fresh catalyst to formaldehyde which, however, rapidly decomposed into CO and H2, while a minor fraction of it was oxidised into CO2 + H2O; therefore, it may be suggested that a fraction of Ga3+ in the fresh catalyst was reduced by methanol (or H2) [55]. In fact, a calculation made by taking reaction stoichiometry and yields into account revealed that over 70% of Ga3+ was reduced to metallic Ga (theoretical reduction 13%, experimental reduction 9.7%). These results indicate that another reason for the initial catalyst deactivation during phenol methylation (and methanol dehydrogenation/decomposition also) may be related to a change in surface characteristics, originating from Ga3+ reduction. After 60 min, a progressive decline in methanol conversion was seen, as well as a similar parallel decrease in yield to CO/H2, while at the same time both the yields to formaldehyde and dimethoxy methane were augmented; in this length of time, both CO2 and H2O formed in very low amounts, and in this case their yields also progressively decreased. Since the distribution of products was not changed, the slow deactivation shown here should be attributed to the formation of heavier products (originating, for instance, from formaldehyde oligomerisation) on the catalyst surface and not to a change in the chemical-physical features of the surface. When phenol is co-fed with methanol, the formaldehyde quickly reacts with the substrate avoiding to undergo further degradation. The role of MgO basic sites lies in its ability to activate phenol as phenolate. The FT-IR study conducted adsorbing phenol under vacuum over MgO and Mg/Ga 10:1 catalyst clearly demonstrated this peculiarity. The spectra obtained by subtracting the catalyst spectrum after pre-treatment at 450 °C under vacuum compared with the pure phenol spectra are reported in the ESI section (Table S3, Figs. S4–S9). The interaction of phenol with the catalytic surface resulted in a perturbation of catalyst hydroxyl groups, which was confirmed by a shift in the band from 3736 to 3700 cm−1. Moreover, the vibration of the phenol OH group at 3558 cm−1 remained noticeable after the adsorption. In the aromatic CH and CC stretching region there was a shift of the bands to lower wavenumbers, in particular the most important difference between the spectra of free and adsorbed phenol concerns the band at 1470 cm−1. During the thermal treatment, the intensity of this band gradually decreased and the band shifted to a higher wavenumber until it was completely enveloped in the band at 1499 cm−1, already shifted to 1492 cm−1. The evidence for the formation of the phenolate species on the surface of catalysts is the disappearance of the band at 1343 cm−1 attributable to the OH bending mode and the concomitant growth of the band at 1289 cm−1 which was attributed to the CO stretching of phenolate species. Overall, the FT-IR analyses of the chemisorbed phenol indicates that phenol is adsorbed as phenolate, following the Tanabe orthogonal mode of adsorption on the active basic sites resulting in the perturbation of vibration modes in ortho and para position [57–59]. Mg/Ga 10:1 catalyst was tested in the 2,6-xylenol methylation with the aim to further increase the 2,4,6-TMP yield, by promoting the mono-alkylation in the para position. The performance of this catalyst is summarised in Fig. 3 , top (reactant mixture with molar ratio of 2,6-xylenol-to-methanol equal to 1:5, at 400 °C). For the sake of comparison, the catalytic behaviour obtained for the 2,6-xylenol methylation over the other considered catalysts (i.e. MgO, Mg/Ga 2:1 and Ga2O3) are reported in the ESI (Fig. S10). As expected, at the beginning of the reaction the main product was 2,4,6-TMP; however, the conversion of 2,6-xylenol was lower compared to phenol, due to both the already occupied, very reactive ortho positions, and the lesser adsorption of the reactant, with the consequent generation of phenolate, due to geometric constraints. This was determined by in-situ FT-IR in vacuum investigation that showed that adsorbed 2,6-xylenol completely desorbs at lower temperature compared to phenol (see FT-IR below). In this case, a decline in conversion was observed during the first 200 min time-on-stream (more significant than from phenol), but afterwards the conversion seemed to stabilise. We did not expect a change in products distribution over time, since the main product, 2,4,6-TMP, is a kinetically primary compound, whose selectivity should not be affected by conversion. Conversely, we noted a surprising decline in selectivity to 2,4,6-TMP and an increasing selectivity to 2,6-DMA and, to a lesser extent, to 2,3,6-TMP as well. Noticeably, these two latter products formed in a non-negligible amount from 2,6-xylenol on fresh catalysts also, whereas they formed in very low amounts from phenol. This effect may be explained by considering the evolution of the active phase during time-on-stream as reported in the previous paragraph, which leads to a decreased production of formaldehyde, in the end to the advantage of the O-alkylation. Noticeably, in the case of phenol methylation over the same Mg/Ga 10:1 catalyst the selectivity to anisoles did not increase with catalyst deactivation. This effect may be explained by considering the higher reactivity of phenol with respect to 2,6-xylenol, due to the two free, very reactive ortho positions that can easily undergo alkylation. Moreover, another key role might be attributed to water that is produced in a small amount from methanol on the fresh catalyst only, but it is a co-product of phenolics methylation. It follows that the formation of water occurs to a much greater extent during phenol methylation than during 2,6-xylenol methylation, because of the following reasons: (i) the lower phenolic/methanol ratio used from phenol than from 2,6-xylenol; (ii) the multi-C-methylation occurring from phenol, versus the predominant mono-methylation from 2,6-xylenol, and (iii) the lower reactivity of 2,6-xylenol compared to phenol. In order to confirm a possible role of water, we conducted experiments of phenol and 2,6-xylenol methylation with the co-feeding of steam. 3.2 The role of steam As expected, co-feeding steam during phenol methylation only led to minor changes in products distribution, but it contributed to delay catalyst deactivation (see Fig. S11 in the ESI). Conversely, water had a great effect in the case of 2,6-xylenol methylation; results of 2,6-xylenol methylation experiments conducted with co-feeding steam are summarised in Fig. 3 bottom for Mg/Ga 10:1 (H2O:2,6-xylenol:CH3OH = 5:1:5 M ratio). Co-feeding steam led to two important effects: (a) 2,6-xylenol conversion increased, compared to experiments without steam, despite the significant deactivation seen during the first 400 min time-on-stream; and (b) the initial high selectivity to 2,4,6-TMP was maintained during time-on-stream despite deactivation and, at the same time, the selectivity to 2,6-DMA remained low. The important effect on anisoles selectivity was mainly attributed to the hydrolysis of these methyl phenyl ethers catalysed by the acidity inferred by Ga (see catalyst characterisation, NH3-TPD, Table S4). De facto, the O-methylation are equilibrium reactions that can be strongly affected by the presence of water (the co-product of the reaction), shifting the equilibria toward the reagents side (Scheme 2 ). To show that this is just the case, DFT calculations were performed to estimate the standard enthalpy and Gibbs energy changes (ΔH° and ΔG°, 298.15 K, 1 bar) both for gas-phase phenol ring methylation and for the formation of methyl ethers; it must be noted that a gas-phase treatment is suitable for the overall thermodynamics, due to the standard states of many species in reaction conditions. The results summarised in Table 1 , show that all alkylation processes are exergonic and exothermic, and that the change in entropy due to alkylation plays a limited role in defining the value of ΔG° (therefore of the equilibrium constants). De facto, ring methylation energetics change very little as a function of the number of the alkyl groups bound to the aryl moiety of the phenol, thus clearly indicating that a cascade alkylation is indeed feasible. Conversely, the limited changes in energetics during the formation of the two ethers (anisole and 2,6-DMA) are interesting; this result is in clear agreement with the decrease in ether formation, which was seen when carrying out reactions in the presence of water steam. In fact, the closeness to unit value of the equilibrium constants for the formation of anisole and 2,6-DMA, which is due to the ΔGo close to zero, proves that the amount of ethers generated is quite sensitive to the amount of water present in the environment. In turn, this suggests that total conversion may also play a role in defining selectivity toward ring-alkylated products versus O-alkylated species, because the more water is released into the reactor, the more the equilibrium describing ether formation is pushed backwards toward reactants. Taking into account the consideration reported above, we compared the results obtained with our best catalyst (Mg/Ga 10:1) with the other oxide materials. Fig. 4 summarises, for the four catalysts studied, the performance with and without steam in 2,6-xylenol methylation; specifically, Fig. 4, top reports the selectivity to main products after approximately 50–80 min time-on-stream, whereas Fig. 4, bottom compares 2,6-xylenol conversion and the selectivity ratio between O-alkylated products (mainly 2,6-DMA) and C-alkylated products (2,4,6-TMP + 2,3,6-TMP). It is important to note that the O-alk/C-alk selectivity ratio should not be affected by conversion, since the formation of 2,6-DMA and TMPs occurs along two parallel routes. The results shown in Fig. 4 confirm that steam co-feeding generally allowed to increase 2,6-xylenol conversion and the importance of this effect decreased in the order MgO > Mg/Ga 10:1 > Mg/Ga 2:1; conversely, with Ga oxide there was a decline in conversion. This may be explained by taking into account the acidity of Ga2O3 able to enhance the hydrolysis of 2,6-DMA back to the reagent (2,6-xylenol). The effect of the increased acidity in the order Ga2O3 > Mg/Ga 2:1 ≥ Mg/Ga 10:1 > MgO led to a corresponding increase of the selectivity to 2,4,6-TMP at the expense of 2,6-DMA selectivity (this effect was less significant in the case of MgO). Even if Ga2O3 is able to activate methanol and generate formaldehyde, its acidity, in dry condition, plays an important role in the formation of anisoles by the activation of methanol as CH3 δ+ (the typical route reported in literature for O-alkylation)[23]. Also the selectivity to 2,3,6-TMP and polyalkylated compounds (mainly TMA) decreased with the co-feeding of steam, especially with Mg/Ga/O catalysts. Overall, in the presence of co-fed steam, the O-alk/C-alk selectivity ratio decreased greatly with all catalysts (Fig. 4 bottom). The effect of steam co-feeding in phenol methylation is shown in Fig. S11 in ESI section. In this case, the effect of steam on the distribution of products was much less important than from 2,6-xylenol. This is not only due to the in-situ formation of water due to the multi-methylation processes as discussed above; but also because in this case anisole underwent consecutive intermolecular and intramolecular rearrangements to the un-occupied ortho positions leading to C-alkylated compounds; this might explain the very low O-alk/C-alk selectivity ratio observed with Mg/Ga/O and Ga2O3. The acidity inferred by Ga (see catalyst characterisation) might foster this rearrangement, as happens in the case of Mg/Al/O catalysts [56]. It is also important to note that in 2,6-xylenol methylation, the formation of 2,6-DMA cannot be limited by consecutive intramolecular rearrangement of the ether methyl group (promoted by the Lewis acidity of Ga in dry conditions), due to the hindrance of both ortho positions. Overall, the effect of steam might be interpreted as follows: (a) it facilitates the hydrolysis of the ethers; this means, however, that the formation of O-methylated compounds is thermodynamically disfavoured under these conditions; and/or (b) it affects the adsorption mode of phenolic reactants and the co-adsorption of methanol. It is also evident that the effect of steam varies depending on the catalyst type. Phenol and 2,6-xylenol adsorptions on Mg/Ga 10:1 were studied by means of in-situ IR spectroscopy, with steam, in order to clarify the role played by water in the reaction. The adsorption of phenol on MgO was also reported for comparison purpose. The nature of free molecule vibrations was interpreted by matching experimental, calculation, and literature data (see Tables S3 and S5 in the ESI). The pre-treatment of catalysts under vacuum at 450 °C (Fig. S12, ESI) made it possible to highlight the relatively higher acidity of Mg/Ga 10:1, compared to pure MgO. The comparison of experimental and calculated frequencies (see Experimental) allowed us to describe the vibrational modes that are essential for understanding the spectra of phenol adsorbed on the Mg/Ga/O catalyst. The spectra reported were obtained by subtracting the catalyst spectrum after pre-treatment at 450 °C under vacuum. Adsorption was performed at room temperature, while desorption was carried out at different temperatures under vacuum. For each series, the spectra recorded after desorption are plotted at increasing temperatures, from room temperature up to 450 °C. The adsorption of phenol over the dry catalytic surface produced a phenolate species orthogonally oriented on the catalyst surface, as reported in the previous paragraph. Concerning the 2,6-xylenol (Figs. 5 and 6 ), when adsorbed on dry catalyst, as in the case of phenol, a perturbation of the OH stretching zone occurred. During the thermal treatment, the two CH aromatic stretching bands at 3096 and 3026 cm−1, with a main component of the hydrogen atom in para position, were shifted to 3068 and 3016 cm−1, respectively, while only a slight effect was revealed for the CH3 stretching modes. As in the case of phenol, the adsorption of 2,6-xylenol led to the formation of the xylenolate as demonstrated by the erosion, at increasing temperature, of the free xylenol CO stretching band at 1197 cm−1 and the concomitant growth of the two bands at 1264 and 1236 cm−1, which were attributed to the CO stretching of xylenolate and xylenol adsorbed species, respectively. The same results were obtained with both MgO and Mg/Ga 10:1. Concerning phenol adsorption, the presence of pre-adsorbed water had two major effects. First, water led to a weaker interaction between phenolate oxygen and Mgδ+ sites, which facilitated the desorption of the substrate. Second, the relatively higher amount of negative charge located on the O atom resulted in a stronger activation of the aromatic ring in the para position (as evidenced by the greater perturbation of the aromatic ring vibrational mode) [57–59]. The effect of water was more evident in the case of 2,6-xylenol; in fact (Fig. S13): i) the shift of the bands at 3096 and 3026 cm−1, with a main component of the hydrogen atom in para position, was more evident in the case of the wet catalyst; ii) in the presence of water the band at 1324 cm−1 (δ OH) remained almost unperturbed also at high temperature. This effect may be attributed to the competitive effect of the adsorption of both water and 2,6-xylenol on the same active site. In the case of 2,6-xylenol, this effect was more evident, compared to phenol, because of the steric hindrance caused by the methyl groups, which rendered the substrate adsorption over a partially water-occupied surface more difficult. Moreover, it should be kept in mind that the presence of water inhibited the deprotonation of the xylenol OH group; iii) in the presence of water, the CO stretching band remained unperturbed up to 200 °C; after this temperature, the formation of adsorbed xylenolate and xylenol was confirmed by the development of the two characteristic IR bands (Fig. S13). Overall, also in the case of 2,6-xylenol, the FT-IR spectroscopy confirmed the strong influence of water on the adsorption of the aromatic substrate. In particular, the presence of water limited the deprotonation to the xylenolate species by decreasing the bond strength between XylO− and Mg2+. This effect might be responsible for the lower nucleophilicity of the O atom in adsorbed xylenol, and thus for the preferred orientation of the electrophilic substitution by the in-situ generated formaldehyde onto the free para position, with formation of 2,4,6-TMP instead of 2,6-DMA. In the absence of steam, conversely, the adsorption and deprotonation of 2,6-xylenol was easier (albeit more difficult than in the case of phenol). Spectroscopic results, however, suggest another important role of water: the co-adsorption of water and phenolics affected the interaction of the aromatic compound with basic sites as well as the deprotonation of the Ph-OH moiety. This effect was more important with 2,6-xylenol (whose adsorption and activation are already hindered) than with phenol, and was significant especially in the case of Ga-containing catalysts (even though water also had some effect in the case of MgO). For example, the increased 2,4,6-TMP formation and the corresponding decreased 2,6-DMA formation observed with co-fed steam (Fig. 4, bottom) may be due to the modified O nucleophilicity and distribution of negative charges in the aromatic ring of the phenolic compound adsorbed on a MgO pair, as a consequence of the perturbation due to water adsorption over the neighbouring Ga site. A competitive adsorption may lead to the weakening of the PhOMg bond strength and, in the end, result in a further activation of the free para position. In order to confirm the electronic effects induced by water co-adsorption, we used DFT modelling to simulate the adsorption of 2,6-xylenol only, and the co-adsorption of 2,6-xylenol and water over both MgO and Ga2O3. Although this may not be the ultimate picture when it comes to describing phenomena occurring on the Mg/Ga/O catalyst surface, it is still useful for inferring a possible role played by water, which might not be a simple spectator, instead affecting the catalytic behaviour. Of course, this information may be of future use for fine-tuning reaction parameters. Table 2 shows the calculated energy for the adsorption of 2,6-xylenol on the MgO surface, with and without the presence of co-adsorbed steam; the optimised structures are shown in Fig. 7 . As commonly found when adsorbing OH-containing molecules, the most stable structures are characterised by a dissociated proton, which strongly binds to an oxygen vicinal to the corner Mg. Furthermore, it should be noted that the xylenol ring is oriented away from the MgO nanocrystal (this is true also for non-alkylated species), making it unlikely for a temporarily surface-adsorbed formaldehyde to attack the phenolic para position, even in the presence of co-adsorbed water, unless the electron-rich ring bends toward the MgO surface. Bent structures, however, should be expected to be substantially higher in energy than the ones shown in Fig. 7, so their relative population should remain low and with a limited impact on the overall reactivity. As for the energetics of the adsorption processes shown in Table 2, it should be noted that the energy released upon the adsorption of 2,6-xylenol on a pristine MgO is 2 kcal/mol larger than for water, a datum that correlates nicely with the slightly stronger acidity of the phenol. Very interestingly, our data also show that the adsorption of both molecules onto an already occupied Mg corner releases much less energy (roughly 12 kcal/mol) than on the pristine counterpart; this change is in excellent agreement with the results from FT-IR desorption experiments, which indicated a much lower desorption temperature for phenols when they are adsorbed in the presence of water vapour. As for the adsorption of water and 2,6-xylenol onto Ga2O3, Table 3 and Fig. 8 provide significant energy and structural details. Overall, the same comments made in the case of MgO may be repeated for the adsorption on gallium oxide also, the only exception being minimum structures that present the aromatic ring somewhat tilted toward the model surface. A “vis-à-vis” comparison between Ga2O3 and MgO energy data, however, highlights that the decrease in 2,6-xylenol adsorption energy onto gallium oxide in the presence of pre-adsorbed water is more pronounced (by roughly 5–6 kcal/mol) than in the case of magnesium oxide. Of course, the net effect of such a greater decrease would be that water facilitates phenol desorption (relatively) more for the former, a result that agrees nicely with the more pronounced impact that the steam has on selectivity when Ga ions are present. To conclude the discussion on DFT data, we wish to point out that there are at least two possible mechanistically significant consequences that emerge from our results. First, lower adsorption energy for phenols should also mean a higher surface mobility and, possibly, a higher likelihood for the ring to be oriented in parallel to the MgO surface. Second, the possibility of displacing the phenols away from the Mg corner site and onto less strongly binding alternative (e.g. edge) locations may permit wider bending movements for the ring, facilitating the electrophilic attack by an adsorbed formaldehyde. Since an in-depth understanding of the impact that might be generated by each possibility would represent a major undertaking, we prefer to postpone such a topic to future studies. 4 Conclusions Investigation of phenol and 2,6-xylenol gas-phase methylation with methanol by means of reactivity tests, in-situ FT-IR spectroscopy, and DFT calculations on MgO, Mg/Ga/O, and Ga2O3 catalysts provided deep insight into the reaction mechanism. MgO showed a very low activity; however, when a very low Ga amount was added to the periclase structure, with a Mg-to-Ga molar ratio of 10:1, phenol conversion increased from about 5% to almost 100%. In-situ FT-IR spectroscopy demonstrated that, in both cases, phenol was adsorbed as phenolate, oriented orthogonally to the catalyst surface, thus making the ortho positions more easily accessible for the electrophilic attack. As a matter of fact, the different activities between these two catalysts are mainly related to the capability of the Ga ion to dehydrogenate methanol into formaldehyde, the latter being the real hydroxyalkylating agent (see Fig. 2) [22,23]. Another important difference between MgO and Mg/Ga/O was the different selectivity to O-alkylated products (mainly anisole and 2,6-DMA). In the case of MgO (see Fig. 1b), two major products, o-cresol and anisole, formed with the anisole selectivity which, however, progressively decreased as time-on-stream increased. Conversely, in the case of Mg/Ga 10:1, only traces of the O-alkylated compounds (mainly 2,6-DMA) were observed, showing the typical behaviour expected for a kinetically consecutive reaction pattern (phenol → o-cresol → 2,6-xylenol → 2,4,6-TMP). These results may be explained considering that: i) Ga was able to produce a large amount of formaldehyde, which was more selective to C-alkylation than to O-alkylation; ii) the Lewis acidity of the Ga sites was able to catalyse the intramolecular rearrangement of the ether methyl group toward the unoccupied ortho positions [56]. Moreover, both catalytic tests and DFT calculation proved that the co-generation of water during the alkylation of phenol affected the products distribution, in particular, lowering the amount of anisoles. This was due to the hydrolysis of the aromatic ether back to phenolic compounds, catalysed by Ga. The key role played by water for the gas-phase alkylation of phenol with methanol – observed during catalytic tests by co-feeding steam – was also explained by means of in-situ FT-IR spectroscopy. The effect of water was more evident in the case of the reaction conducted from 2,6-xylenol; in fact, in the case of phenol methylation, a large quantity of water was coproduced during the consecutive reaction pattern described above, and therefore a further addition of steam did not affect the products distribution so much. During 2,6-xylenol methylation with Mg/Ga 10:1 in the absence of co-fed water, the formation of 2,6-DMA was predominant due to the unavailability of both ortho positions which prevented the intramolecular rearrangement of the methyl group and also hindered the orthogonal adsorption of the reactant in the form of xylenolate, as evidenced by in-situ FT-IR. However, when steam was co-fed, the 2,6-DMA yield dramatically dropped, permitting an almost stable production of 2,4,6-TMP. In-situ FT-IR and DFT calculation results demonstrated that, in the presence of adsorbed water: i) the adsorption energies of phenolics are lower compared to the dry catalyst, also stabilising the undissociated form; ii) the para position of the aromatic ring is more perturbed and this effect is more evident in Ga-containing systems; iii) the aromatic ring tends to bend toward the surface, thus facilitating the electrophilic attack in para position; and iv) the presence of water strongly affects the equilibrium of ethers formation promoting their hydrolysis, as proved by DFT calculations. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, we report on a new catalyst type based on Mg/Ga/O for the gas-phase methylation of phenol with the aim of obtaining the synthesis of 2,4,6-trimethylphenol. This catalyst showed an outstanding performance compared to similar catalysts reported in the literature, with high yield to the desired product. Reasons for this excellent performance were related to the high activity in methanol dehydrogenation to formaldehyde, which is the rate-limiting step in the multi-step (but one-pot) process, as well as to the moderate acidic features due to Ga sites, which enhanced the intramolecular rearrangement of O-alkylated compounds. The surprising role for co-fed steam, which greatly enhanced the selectivity to 2,4,6-trimethylphenol, was also investigated, combining reactivity experiments, in-situ FT-IR spectroscopy, and DFT calculations. It was found that the co-adsorption of water significantly affects the chemo-selectivity of the reaction, thus decreasing the formation of O-alkylated compounds in favour of the desired C-alkylated compounds. Reasons for catalyst deactivation were also studied.
coredata.dc:title: Mg/Ga mixed-oxide catalysts for phenol methylation: Outstanding performance in 2,4,6-trimethylphenol synthesis with co-feeding of water
